description: According to Some Folklore of Trees, Animals, and River-fishing from the N.E. of Scotland, "The wood of the 'hackberry' or bird-cherry (Prunus padus) is not used as a staff or for any other purpose, as it is looked on as the witch's tree."

entries.meaning: Prunus padus, a species of cherry native to northern Europe and northern Asia, the bird cherry.
Its bittersweet astringent fruit, readily eaten by birds.
